article:
'Ali{{okina}}i' is a word in some Polynesian languages denoting chiefly
status in ancient Hawaii and the Samoa Islands.

A similar word with the same concept is found in other Polynesian societies. In
the Cook Islands, an [[ariki]] is a high chief and the House of Ariki is a
parliamentary house (with very limited power). In New Zealand a MÄori [[ariki]]
held a rank of nobility and the Maori monarch held the title Te Arikinui (Great
Chief) similar to Ke Ali{{okina}}i Nui in Hawaiian. In Tokelau, the term aliki
denotes a chief, on Easter Island a noble was ariki, in Gambier Islands akariki,
and in Tahiti the term is ari'i.

In Samoa, ali'i is a chiefly rank in the [[fa'amatai]] system which lies at the
heart of the culture's socio-political organisation {{cite
encyclopedia |url=http://www.google.co.nz/books?id=wNDgF7Y9hr4C&lpg=PP1&dq=Land-
%20rights%20of%20Pacific%20women%E2%80%8E&pg=PA103#v=onepage&q=&f=false
|encyclopedia=Land Rights of Pacific Women |title=Western Samoa: the sacred
covenant |first=Aiono |last=Fana'afi Le Tagaloa |page=103 |year=1986
|publisher=Institute of Pacific Studies of the University of the South Pacific
|isbn=982-02-0012-1 |accessdate=6 July 2010 }} and similar to the
traditional system in Hawaii.
